problem.tex: Find the Laurent series of $f(z)=\frac{1}{z(z-1)(3z-2)}$ inside the annulus $\frac{1}{6}<\left|z-\frac{1}{2}\right|<\frac{1}{2}$.

solution.tex: By partial fraction decomposition, this function can be written as, \[f(z)=\frac{1}{2z}+\frac{1}{z-1}+\frac{-9}{2(3z-2)}\] We can rewrite, \[\frac{1}{2z}+\frac{1}{z-1}+\frac{-9}{2(3z-2)}=\frac{1}{2(z-\frac{1}{2})+1}+\frac{-2}{-2(z-\frac{1}{2})+1}+\frac{-9}{2(3z-2)}\] Whenever, $\left| z-\frac{1}{2} \right| < \frac{1}{2}$, the first two terms have an expansion of, \[\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^{n} 2^{n} \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)^{n}-2 \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 2^{n} \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)^{n}\] Now on, \[\left| z-\frac{1}{2} \right|> \frac{1}{6}\] We have that, \[\frac{-9}{2(3z-2)}=\frac{\frac{-3}{2}}{\left(z-\frac{1}{2} \right)\left(1-\frac{1}{6 (z-\frac{1}{2})} \right)}\] The Laurent series is thus, \[\frac{-3}{2 \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 6^{-n} \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)^{-n}=\frac{-3}{2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 6^{-n} \left( z- \frac{1}{2} \right)^{-n-1}\] Therefore, summing up, the Laurent series for this function is, \[\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} (-1)^{n} 2^{n} \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)^{n}- \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 2^{n+1} \left( z-\frac{1}{2} \right)^{n} -\frac{3}{2} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} 6^{-n} \left( z- \frac{1}{2} \right)^{-n-1}\]
